If Planet 9 is that big probably, there would be internal heating due to massive pressure. But if the crust is particularly thick it might be unlikely to have active volcanism as it might be tectonically locked. Remember a large part of Earths crust is believed to be what makes up the Moon. So our crust is thinner than it would otherwise have been. Venus shows an active volcanic past. But it's not generally believed to be currently active. It's quite possible a Planet 9 could have a volcanic history with no current activity. The question then would be, would the internal heat keep it's atmosphere from freezing solid.

I suspect if there is a super earth out there its either a semi gaseous planet with a rocky core but a thick dense atmosphere like that of Titan or its a solid rock and ice world similar to Pluto, with water ice and next to no atmosphere.
